repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Turkish Electricity Authority
            (TEK) Restructuring Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact substantial. Key lessons highlight,
            first, the need for having a legal framework in place, prior
            to privatization to avoid unnecessary legal/constitutional
            barriers, and economic/legal constraints to private
            investment in new power plants, which delayed
            implementation. In order to attract private investors, the
            Government had to provide price, and off-take guarantees for
            power plants using the Build-On-Transfer (BOT), as well as
            the more successful Build-Own-Operate (BOO) model.
            Nonetheless, the passage of the new Electric Energy Market
            Law will set a new framework, which will allow private power
            plants to operate without Government guarantees. Second,
            contracts with the private sector for large investments,
            such as power plants, should not be negotiated on a sole
            source basis; rather, contracting should undergo a bidding
            process. This should prevent the extremely high prices,
            erroneously negotiated, and agreed by the Ministry of Energy
            and Natural Resources. Third, details for using an
            acceptable model, i.e. the BOT model, should be clearly
            understood by both the Bank, and Government to appropriately
            deal with contracting negotiations. Fourth, management
            changes among implementing agencies, reduces effectiveness,
            and slows decision-making.
